planets.title: ADHD Support
planets.description: Practical tools for attention, focus, and time management when your brain has twenty tabs open at once.

did_you_know: Did you know ADHD can make time feel invisible? Your brain doesn't track time passing the same way.
ADHD brains produce less dopamine, which is why boring tasks feel physically painful.
Task initiation paralysis is real—your brain struggles to start tasks even when you desperately want to.
ADHD affects working memory, so 'out of sight, out of mind' is painfully literal.
ADHD can make you feel physical pain from boredom. It's not laziness—it's neurological.
Hyperfocus isn't a superpower when you forget to eat, sleep, or use the loo.
ADHD brains are interest-based, not importance-based.
Time blindness means you genuinely don't know if something took 5 minutes or 50.
ADHD often comes with Rejection Sensitive Dysphoria (RSD).
ADHD brains crave stimulation. Fidgeting is your brain creating the dopamine it needs.
Emotional regulation is part of ADHD—your feelings can feel overwhelming.
ADHD often means 'time optimism'—thinking you have more time than you do.
Sleep problems are neurological with ADHD—your brain doesn't produce melatonin on schedule.
ADHD makes transitions feel like climbing mountains—task switching drains massive energy.
Object permanence struggles are real—you forget things exist when you can't see them.

planets.title: Autism Support
planets.description: Sensory tools, social scripts, and acceptance for your beautiful autistic brain.

did_you_know: Autism is a neurological difference, not a disorder to be fixed.
Masking is exhausting—pretending to be neurotypical drains massive energy.
Autistic burnout is real and can last months or years.
Sensory overload isn't dramatic—it's your nervous system being genuinely overwhelmed.
Stimming helps regulate your nervous system—it's not something to suppress.
Many autistic people have alexithymia—difficulty identifying their own emotions.
Meltdowns aren't tantrums—they're nervous system overload and loss of control.
Shutdowns are when your brain goes into protection mode and you can't respond.
Special interests aren't 'obsessions'—they're sources of joy, meaning, and regulation.
Autistic people often have extreme sensory sensitivities or seeking behaviours.
Social communication differences don't mean you don't want connection.
Routine and predictability aren't 'rigid'—they're how autistic brains feel safe.
Many autistic people are hypersensitive to injustice and lying.
Eye contact can be painful or overwhelming—it's not rudeness.
Autistic people often think in pictures, patterns, or systems rather than words.

planets.title: Anxiety Tools
planets.description: Grounding techniques, breathing exercises, and tools for when your nervous system is stuck in overdrive.

did_you_know: Anxiety is your nervous system trying to protect you—it's not weakness.
Your body can't tell the difference between real danger and perceived threat.
Grounding techniques work by bringing you back to the present moment.
The physiological sigh (two inhales, long exhale) is scientifically proven to calm anxiety.
Anxiety loves 'what if' thinking—grounding breaks that cycle.
Your body holds anxiety—it's not 'all in your head'.
Panic attacks can't actually hurt you, even though they feel terrifying.
Avoidance makes anxiety stronger—gentle, gradual exposure helps.
Anxiety often gets worse before it gets better when you start challenging it.
Your anxious thoughts aren't facts—they're just your brain's threat detector on high alert.
Cold water on your face activates the dive reflex, instantly calming anxiety.
Naming your emotions reduces their intensity—'I'm feeling anxious' helps more than you'd think.
Anxiety often peaks at about 10 minutes, then naturally starts to decrease.
Bilateral stimulation (tapping, walking, eye movements) can reduce anxiety quickly.
Anxiety is often trying to tell you something—but not what you think it is.

planets.title: Depression Support
planets.description: Gentle strategies for low motivation, self-compassion, and tiny steps forward when everything feels heavy.

did_you_know: Depression isn't sadness—it's often numbness, emptiness, or heaviness.
Low motivation with depression is neurological, not laziness.
A 'no zero days' approach means even tiny actions count.
Depression lies—your brain tells you things that aren't true.
Behavioural activation (doing things even when you don't feel like it) is proven to help.
Depression makes time feel weird—minutes feel like hours, days blur together.
You don't have to feel motivated to do things—action can come before motivation.
Depression affects your memory, concentration, and decision-making.
Self-compassion is scientifically more effective than self-criticism for recovery.
Depression often comes with physical symptoms: pain, fatigue, digestive issues.
Anhedonia (not enjoying things you used to love) is a symptom, not who you are.
Depression can make you forget you've ever felt better—but you have, and will again.
Minimum baseline routines protect you when you can't manage 'normal'.
Depression recovery isn't linear—bad days don't erase your progress.
You deserve care and support even if you 'can't explain why' you're depressed.

planets.title: Parenting Hub
planets.description: Therapeutic parenting strategies, managing behaviours, and looking after yourself whilst caring for neurodivergent children.

did_you_know: Behaviour is communication—your child is trying to tell you something.
Meltdowns aren't manipulation—they're genuine nervous system overload.
You can't parent your way out of neurodivergence—and you shouldn't try.
Co-regulation (helping your child regulate by staying calm yourself) is powerful.
Neurodivergent children often need connection before correction.
Your child's brain develops differently—'typical' parenting advice often doesn't work.
Demand avoidance isn't defiance—it's a nervous system response to perceived pressure.
Sensory needs aren't preferences—they're neurological requirements.
Your child's struggles are real, even if they don't 'look' disabled to others.
You're allowed to grieve the parenting experience you expected whilst loving your child.
Neurodivergent parents often understand neurodivergent children deeply.
It's okay to not enjoy every moment—parenting is hard, neurodivergent parenting is harder.
Your child needs you to be regulated more than they need you to be perfect.
Accommodations aren't 'giving in'—they're meeting genuine needs.
You're not failing—you're parenting a child with different needs in a world not built for them.

planets.title: Neurodivergent & Work
planets.description: Workplace strategies, interview support, and managing work whilst neurodivergent (not legal/benefits advice).

did_you_know: Many workplaces aren't designed for neurodivergent brains—it's not you, it's them.
Masking at work is exhausting and leads to burnout.
You're allowed to ask for accommodations—they're adjustments, not special treatment.
Open plan offices are sensory nightmares for many neurodivergent people.
Working from home isn't 'easier'—it removes sensory/social barriers.
Neurodivergent people often bring unique strengths: creativity, pattern recognition, focus.
Interviews disadvantage neurodivergent people—you're not bad at your job, you're bad at performing 'professionalism'.
Job hopping is common with ADHD/Autism—it's often about finding the right fit.
Burnout at work looks different for neurodivergent people.
You're not failing if you can't work full-time—capitalism isn't designed for disabled people.
Neurodivergent people often need longer to process information—asking for time isn't weakness.
Email communication can be easier than face-to-face for many autistic people.
Flexible hours can make or break your ability to work.
You don't have to disclose your neurodivergence—but sometimes it helps.
Not everyone can 'just push through'—and that's okay.

planets.title: Relationships
planets.description: Communication tools, boundaries, and understanding neurodivergent relationships.

did_you_know: Neurodivergent people often communicate love differently—it's not less, it's different.
Many autistic people struggle with 'reading between the lines'—direct communication helps.
ADHD can make you 'out of sight, out of mind' with relationships—it's not that you don't care.
Rejection Sensitive Dysphoria can make relationship conflicts feel devastating.
Masking in relationships leads to resentment and exhaustion.
You're allowed to have different social/sensory needs than your partner.
Double empathy problem: neurotypicals misunderstand autistic people as much as vice versa.
Parallel play (being together whilst doing separate things) is valid quality time.
You don't owe anyone eye contact, hugs, or small talk—even in relationships.
Alexithymia makes it hard to identify and communicate your own emotions.
Sensory sensitivities affect intimacy—and that's okay to discuss.
Neurodivergent relationships have unique strengths: loyalty, honesty, deep connection.
You might need more or less social contact than your partner—both are valid.
Miscommunication doesn't mean incompatibility—it means you need clearer systems.
Your neurodivergence is part of you, not something to 'manage' in relationships.
overlaps: Autism (communication differences, social energy, sensory needs)
Anxiety (social anxiety, relationship OCD, reassurance seeking)

planets.title: Time Management
planets.description: Scheduling, prioritising, planning, and managing transitions when time feels impossible.

did_you_know: Time blindness is a real neurological difference—you're not 'bad with time'.
Transitions between tasks require executive function—they're genuinely exhausting.
Your brain might genuinely not know if something took 5 minutes or 2 hours.
Time management tools designed for neurotypicals often don't work for neurodivergent brains.
Visual time (seeing time shrink/grow) works better than abstract clocks.
Time anxiety is when you're constantly worried about being late or missing things.
Parkinson's Law: tasks expand to fill available time—deadlines can help with ADHD.
Time optimism (thinking you have more time than you do) is common with ADHD.
Routines reduce decision fatigue—your brain doesn't have to plan everything daily.
Buffer time (extra time between tasks) prevents cascading lateness.
External time cues (alarms, timers, other people) help when internal time sense fails.
Hyperfocus makes time disappear—you're not choosing to lose track.
Morning and evening routines fail when they're too ambitious—minimum baseline works better.
You might need 3x longer than 'normal' for transitions—that's your brain, not your fault.
Calendar/planner systems only work if you can actually see them regularly.
overlaps: Autism (routine needs, transition difficulty, change anxiety)

planets.title: Dyslexia & Dyscalculia
planets.description: Reading tools, maths support, assistive technology, and celebrating your unique brain.

did_you_know: Dyslexia affects about 10% of the population—you're not alone.
Dyslexic brains often excel at big-picture thinking, creativity, and problem-solving.
Reading difficulty doesn't mean low intelligence—dyslexia is a processing difference.
Dyscalculia is 'dyslexia for maths'—number sense difficulties are real.
Audio books 'count' as reading—absorbing stories matters, not how you do it.
Dyslexia can affect spelling, reading, writing, and sometimes speech.
Many dyslexic people see letters/numbers moving, swapping, or jumping.
Overlays (coloured filters) genuinely help some people with visual stress.
Dyscalculia can make telling time, handling money, and measuring difficult.
You can be highly articulate verbally but struggle to write—it's the processing, not the thinking.
Dyslexia affects working memory—you might forget instructions immediately.
Many successful people are dyslexic—different processing can be a strength.
Assistive technology (text-to-speech, speech-to-text) is a tool, not 'cheating'.
Dyslexia and dyscalculia often co-occur with ADHD, autism, or dyspraxia.
Your brain works differently—schools often aren't set up for you, but that's their failing, not yours.

planets.title: Chronic Illness Resources
planets.description: Pacing, energy management, physiotherapy, and living well with chronic physical health conditions.

did_you_know: Chronic illness is often invisible—you don't 'look sick' but you're still genuinely ill.
Spoon theory helps explain limited energy: you start each day with limited 'spoons'.
Pacing (balancing activity and rest) prevents boom-bust cycles.
Post-exertional malaise (PEM) means activity makes you worse days later—not immediately.
Chronic pain and fatigue are real, physical symptoms—not 'in your head'.
Many chronic illnesses have no cure—learning to live well with illness is valid.
Grief for your pre-illness life is real and deserves space.
Energy accounting (tracking what depletes/replenishes you) helps manage limited capacity.
Rest is not laziness—it's medical management.
Flare-ups don't mean you're doing something wrong—chronic illness fluctuates.
Asking for help isn't failure—it's adapting to your reality.
Many chronic illnesses overlap with neurodivergence (EDS, POTS, ME/CFS, fibromyalgia).
Physiotherapy can help—but it needs to respect your limits, not push through them.
You're allowed to grieve your old life whilst building a new one.
Your illness is real even if doctors haven't found answers yet.

planets.title: Memory Tools
planets.description: Working memory strategies, recall aids, reminders, and systems for when your brain forgets everything.

did_you_know: Working memory is like your brain's RAM—it holds information temporarily whilst you use it.
Many neurodivergent people have impaired working memory—it's neurological, not stupidity.
You can forget what someone said mid-sentence—that's working memory, not disrespect.
External memory systems (notes, reminders, systems) compensate for faulty internal memory.
Forgetting doesn't mean you don't care—memory and caring are different brain systems.
Prospective memory (remembering to do future things) often fails with ADHD/Autism.
Context-dependent memory: you remember things better in the place you learned them.
Multi-tasking destroys working memory—you're not bad at it, it's genuinely impossible.
Sleep and stress massively affect memory—chronic sleep debt makes everything worse.
Chunking (grouping information) helps overwhelmed working memory.
Visual memory often works better than verbal memory for many people.
Writing things down isn't admitting defeat—it's smart external memory management.
You can have excellent long-term memory but terrible working memory.
ADHD medication can significantly improve working memory for some people.
Your memory struggles are real and deserve accommodation.

planets.title: Dyspraxia
planets.description: Motor skills, coordination, proprioception, and movement support for your beautiful clumsy brain.

did_you_know: Dyspraxia affects motor planning—your brain struggles to plan and coordinate movements.
It's not just 'being clumsy'—it's a neurological processing difference.
Dyspraxia can affect gross motor (running, balance) and fine motor (handwriting, buttons) skills.
Many people with dyspraxia have poor proprioception—you don't always know where your body is in space.
Dyspraxia can affect speech (verbal dyspraxia) and make coordinating mouth movements hard.
You might bump into things constantly—your brain misjudges spatial distances.
Handwriting can be physically exhausting and painful with dyspraxia.
Dyspraxia often comes with organisational and planning difficulties.
Many people with dyspraxia are hypermobile—loose joints make coordination harder.
Balance and vestibular issues are common—you might feel dizzy or unsteady often.
Dyspraxia can affect auditory processing—following verbal instructions is genuinely harder.
Timing and rhythm difficulties mean dancing, catching balls, and sports are challenging.
You might be able to think through movements but your body won't cooperate.
Dyspraxia often overlaps with ADHD, autism, dyslexia, and hypermobility conditions.
Your coordination struggles are real—you're not lazy or not trying hard enough.
